newsitem.title: HONG KONG: Shenzhen B index ends sideways on A, HK indices.
newsitem.headline: Shenzhen B index ends sideways on A, HK indices.

text.p: Shenzhen's B share index ended marginally higher on Wednesday, encouraged by the Hong Kong stock market hitting a record high but depressed by weaker local A shares, analysts said.
The foreign currency B index edged up 0.27 points or 0.18 percent to 151.34 on turnover of HK$126.9 million against Tuesday's HK$144.4 million.
"The B index was caught between the A shares and the Hong Kong index," an analyst at China Guotai Securities said.
Hong Kong stocks closed the Wednesday morning session at an all-time high, riding on renewed red-chip fever -- Hong Kong shares with China backing, brokers said.
The Hang Seng index closed the morning one percent higher at a record 14,685.52.
The B share investors were however edgy about aftershocks from China's government policies to cool the markets and held back after the local currency A index dropped, analysts said.
The A index slid 3.64 points or 0.83 percent to 436.84 on turnover of 6.5 billion yunn, compared with Tuesday's 6.9 billion.
"The A share investors are largely focused on Beijing's possible clampdown on the markets," an analyst at a major western investment bank said.
State media said on Wednesday the China Securities Regulatory Commission (CSRC) had set up two special phone lines for investors to report irregularities and illegal trading on the stock markets.
"People see the phone lines as a warning against stock speculation," the analyst said.
Beijing began to implement policies to dampen stock speculation at the start of May, by which time the A and B indices had surged more than 50 percent from the beginning of 1997.
Weifu Fuel Injection Co Ltd was the best performer in the B share market and added HK$0.34 or 6.77 percent to HK$5.36.
